item.title: Test Post
item.description: This is my cat! =^._.^= Heading of my post! Content of my post! Subheading More content hist(quakes$mag) quakes <- quakes import re match=re.match(r"\d+", "SDS348") r.quakes.mag.mean() ## 4.6204000000000001 How to Upload to GitHub ek8435@educcomp04:~/website$ cd /website/public ek8435@educcomp04:/website/public$ pwd /stor/home/ek8435/website/public ek8435@educcomp04:~/website/public$ git init Initialized empty Git repository in /stor/home/ek8435/website/public/.git/ ek8435@educcomp04:~/website/public$ git add . ek8435@educcomp04:~/website/public$ git commit -m "test site" ek8435@educcomp04:~/website/public$ git remote add origin https://github.com/estherewing/estherewing.github.io.git ek8435@educcomp04:~/website/public$ git push origin master

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Modeling Guidelines and Rubric 0. (5 pts) Introduce your dataset and each of your variables (or just your main variables if you have lots) in a paragraph. What are they measuring? How many observations? My dataset contains data regarding global land temperature change of major cities in the world collected from 1849 to 2013. The variables of this dataset are date (dt), average temperature, average temperature uncertainty, city, country, latitude, and longitude.

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Esther Kim (ek8435) Data Wrangling and Data Exploration Rubric Prerequisite: Finding appropriate data from at least two sources per the instructions above: Failure to do this will result in a 0! You will submit a .Rmd file and a knitted document (pdf). 0. Introduction (4 pts) Write a narrative introductory paragraph or two describing the datasets you have chosen, the variables they contain, how they were acquired, and why they are interesting to you.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.
